text: low speed vehicle collision between a client (bp) employee and wg employee in the cp car park. migrated from legacy cairs incident #33700a wg alcs employee (richard haworth)reported that he wasdriving towards the compass point car park exit barrier when a car pulled out of a parking space onhis left hand side and collided with the side of his car, causingdamage to the side doors of his car and thefront bumper of the other car. theotherindividual (stephen bradshaw- client employee - bp) provided hisversion of events, statingthat the conditions were sunny andhe had sun inhis eyes. hechecked andit appeared clear butpulled out of the space and collided with the other vehicle. he believe that whilsthe exited without the path forward being clear, the accident was preventable if the other vehicle had exited at appropriate speed.the speed limit within the car park is 10mph. it was a low speed incident and no injuries occurred. the incident was reported to the wg hssea team by the wg employee. it is unknown if the client employee reported the incident to the client's hssea team/ management. incident investigation notes:individuals to provide their version of events, cctv footage to be reviewed and incident site to be assessed, all by20/04/2017.wg employee stated he was travelling at 5-6mph (within 10mph speed limit) when the client employee pulled out of aparking space on the left hand side and collided with his vehicle. the client employee’s response following the incidentwas “i did not see you”. wg employee assumes the client employee was looking left instead of right when he was pullingout, as he was turning left at the time, and his impression was that the client employee drove straight into the side of hiscar without breaking. it is reported that the client employee was wearing very dark glasses – possibility photochromic –when he got out of his car, as the wg employee could not see his eyes through them.client employee states that theconditions were sunny and he had sun in his eyes. he checked the way forward which appeared clear but he collided withthe other vehicle. he believes that whilst he exited without the path forward being clear, the accident was preventable ifthe other vehicle had exited at appropriate speed. however, in subsequent correspondence he stated that the collisionimpact was less than 5 mph. he confirms he was wearing his prescription sunglasses and stated that glare was definitelya contributing factor as he had direct sunlight in his eyes. he advised that he had a head cold at the time of the incidentbut does not believe this was a contributing factor and, although it was not something he considered at the time, due to itbeing the end of the working day his mind could possibly have been occupied with other things. finally, the clientemployee advised that there is an internal pillar in the windscreen of his vehicle which gives a 2-3cm blind spot to the righthad side, which added to the sun position obscuring his vision. cctv footage has been viewed. although it is not overlyclear due to restricted view, the wg employee does not appear to be travelling at excessive speed. however, the clientemployee does appear to have driven straight out of the space, without consideration that a vehicle may approach fromhis right hand corner. in addition, following assessment of the incident location at the same time the next day, it wasidentified that the clients vehicle was parked facing north and the suns position at 16:40 is south west. this evidentiallyputs the suns position at the time of the incident behind the clients vehicle, not in front of him or in his direct line of vision.the car park surface, lighting, safety control measures etc. are inspected on a regular basis and maintained accordingly;neither party advised of any car park aspects as a contributing factor. all facts considered, it has been concluded that thecollision was a result of incorrect judgment and poor co-ordination / reaction time of the client employee.this report will beprovided to the client and any action taken will be recorded accordingly. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description
ie reported with eye irritation ie reported with irritation to left eye eye was flushed

ie reported soreness and weakness in arms on 3/19/2016, possibly due to manual lifting on 3/16/2016 on 3/19/2016, ie reported to the safety office of generalized soreness and weakness in both arms, possibly due to an incident that had happened on 3/16/2016.  on 3/16/2016, a dozer had rolled a large clump of dirt into an a/c trench on top of the previously installed cable.  the ie entered the trench and manually removed the clump of dirt himself.  the ie stated following lifting the dirt he has experienced soreness, weakness, and minor tingling sensations.on 3/21/2016, ie reported that he continued to experience pain upon movement in both biceps and requested evaluation by a physician.  upon evaluation, physician found a minor strain in the ie's right bicep and recommended heat therapy and prescription strength otc medication. no treatment given at time of report.  on 3/21/2016, ie taken to physician for evaluation and diagnosed with mild bicep strain.

category: lifting or moving loads, vehicle incident general
text: while the manitou was passing through the nhf, assisted by the spotter, the trailer hit the existing scaffold on the right side.  at approx. 13.30u on wednesday the 6th of april, a manitou driver drove with his trailer into the nhf. the manitou driver was assisted by one spotter. in the morning the scaffold company build a bridge on request of vanhout, to pour the concrete in the afternoon. because of this scaffolding bridge and an existing scaffold on the other side of the road the road became very narrow. while the manitou was passing through the nhf, assisted by the spotter, the trailer hit the existing scaffold on the right side. the ladder of this scaffold was hit and two supporting tubes were bended there was no one on top of the scaffold and nobody was in direct danger. fact; the manitou and his trailer had no problems in the morning while driving through the nhf. because the bridge was added to the area, the same road became narrower (lack of risk assessment). this change was made during the morning, but was not managed properly (moc).the weather conditions: was clear and dry. workspace condition: because of the scaffolds there was a limited workspace for machinery to pass through.   activity immediately stopped by vanhout and the incident is reported to afw and altrad the scaffolding company. in corporation with em and afw an alcohol test is done (for the driver and spotter as well). the tests were negative.investigation regarding the incident is done by afw and vanhout.

s/c fire guard got a particle in his right eye which caused scratches on his cornea and required treatment at fa clinic s/c fire guard got a particle in his right eye which caused scratches on his cornea and required treatment at fa clinicon the 9th of september are the ip felt something in his right eye while standing in the laydown area executing fire guard duties to cover the activities performed by the e&i contractor. at first the ip contacted his supervisor to seek advice but being his supervisor not immediately available ip decided to self-treat the eye issue by using a bottle containing eye washing solution to remove the particle from his eye. ip repeated eye washing operation 3 times from 11:00 to 14:00 as this was reliving the itchy feeling from his eye. at 14:00 ip contacted again his supervisor which at this time went to collect ip from site and guided him to site fa clinic where ip received treatment including eye inspection, no particles or objet were found but cornea was found to be scratched, and a nonprescription eye ointment.on the 10th of september at around 20:00 the ip felt an increasing discomfort to his injured eye and after trying to contact the clinic ip decided to visit and external doctor to seek advice.external doctor prescribed a different medication to treat his eye containing antibiotic.ip was wearing all required ppe at the time of the event which included safety glasses. fa clinic intervention

report only due to ic contractor reporting to client woodside.a package of one litre tin of sika primer was found to contain corroded and leaking tin. migrated from legacy cairs incident #32420report only due to ic contractor reporting to client woodside.a package of one litre tin of sika primer was found to contain corroded and leaking tin. immediate action: determined correct disposal routes for contents and tins and disposed of them.hazard report only.brownfields contractor crew were unpacking a materials container on the gwa pipe deck. while unpacking the container an unusual smell was noticed.the crew found a box marked "sika primer 210t" which was wrapped in a waterproof membrane. the box was opened found to contain 8 tins of sika primer.all cans had varying degrees of corrosion and one can was leaking. the leak was contained within the packaging.all cans in the box were removed and disposed of.other boxes of sika primer were checked and found to be in good condition and removed to the appropriate chemical store. note from gwa storeman: the cans were suitable packaging for the contents other than looking quite old & rusty.the purchase order that these items were purchased on was delivered in november 2016 and have been stored at pdc since then. the packaging looks like the carton has been re-wrapped with non-clear plastic overpacking thus rendering any visual inspection impossible unless unpacked.there are several unknown variables in this event which cannot be determined e.g. cause of corrosion for this one package given that all others were unmarked. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

employee pinched finger staging torque tubes for forklift pickup on tuesday, october 20th, 2020 at approximately 3:45pm est, two employees were assisting in loading torque tubes on a forklift. the employee was counting the tubes and positioning toprque tubes to be picked up by a forklift. during the positioning of the tubes, another employee on the opposite end moved a torque tube into the pile to be picked up by the forklift. this action caused the tube end to pinch the right middle finger of the ip. an actual rating of b1 was given due to the first aid treatment (ice pack) applied to the ip's finger. a potential of b2 was given for the potential of the injury being more severe and require medical treatment had the ip's hand been positioned differently. employee notified the foreman who brought the ip to the on-site medic for evaluation. investigation procedues were initiated by hsse.

light vehicle has made contact with the lifting point of a concrete block while giving way to another light vehicle has made contact with the lifting point of a concrete block while giving way to another vehicle. vehicle parked up, supervisor notified, scene preserved, investigation commenced.

cut to finger from metal paper fastener ip was handling a pack of paperwork which was held together using a metal re-useable paper fastener. as they picked up the pack their finger moved along the metal fastener resulting in a cut. incident was reported to a first aider who cleaned the cut and applied a plaster. metal re-useable paper fastener was replaced with a plastic version.

a wood contractor resulted positive from rt pcr test  reference to the recent bcp activated in shallow water platform, a contractor resulted positive from rt-pcr test.  the case has been communicated to their respective oh teams and contract holders. wood oh team is closely monitoring for their recovery.  the case was referred to the local government health team for coordination and recording. ip is now monitored by the contractor's oh team and personnel identified as close contacts were recommended to do a home quarantine for 14 days.

individual tested tested positive for covid-19  ip tested positive on12th may 2020 now already tested negative , however he  didn’t inform us as it occurred outside of work.  ip tested positive for covid on 12th may and has now recovered.he is currently under self-isolation and was tested negative yesterday, he will be having his second test administered tomorrow

a psns subcontractor tested positive for covid-19. it has been reported today a psns office based subcontractor was admitted to hospital with covid-19 symptoms and after pcr test received positive result. this is an office based subcontractor however employee was on remote work. 25/05/2021 ip was hospitalized and now is under doctor's supervision receiving medical treatment, general health condition is stable. date of the next pcr test to be advised. employee hospitalized and receiving medical treatment.

during cutting of concrete slab, a rainwater sewer pipe was damaged vsh started the concrete works as per drawing. the prescribed depth was not matching the drawings. this resulted in cutting the rainwater sewer pipe. the drawings did not indicate the pipe. stopped the work. informed em console to install a rubber plug.

employee suspected of being under the influence of uncontrolled substance   at approximately 5:45pm during a walk of the site parking lot the project manager noticed employee appearing to be sleeping in his vehicle. pm checked on employee and when the employee woke up he stepped out of vehicle dropping an unknown substance onto the ground. the employee demonstrated signs of  influence of uncontrolled substance.  local law enforcement was contacted and responded, removing the employee from site

employee pcr positive for covid-19 employee tested positive for covid-19.  ip currently recovering at home.  ip was currently working from and have not been in the office. no identified close contact as ip is currently working from home.

a wood employee strained his knee while standing up.   on 4-19-2021 at approximately 9:00 am, the ip was tasked with draining water from a line at the pod 18-45-77 location which required him to kneel to complete.  after completing the task, he closed the valve and when he stood up, he felt a strain in his right leg below the knee cap.  actual severity is b1 because the injury required first aid measures.  the potential severity is a b1 because it is unlikely that the injury that resulted from standing up could have required more than first aid measures. the ip reported the injury the hssea advisor.  axiom was contacted.

wood employee tested positive for covid 19, no symptoms. ip tested positive for covid 19. ip went for a test as his flatmate was positive. ip is not exhibiting any symptoms. ip was advised to do self quarantine at home by haad.

workers was tested positive for covid-19 (c+) wood engineer visited the doctor due to ill health during the annual leave(21 oct 2021) and was examined by a doctor who confirmed that he had covid positive. his last working day was 20 october 2021. as per the moh guidelines he was isolated at home.  engaged disinfection company to do disinfection on the affected area(wood office level 1 ). covid positive (c+) cases reported to statutory body on 22th oct 2021.(bca)

wood subcontracted taxi was involved in a road traffic accident. there were no injuries as a result of the incident and minor damage. whilst travelling from the employees home in abu dhabi to the wood office in dubai (arenco tower) a taxi carrying a wood employee was involved in a road traffic accident on sheikh zayed road next to the al shahama petrol station slip road at approximately 07:10. it was a clear sunny day and there were no obstructions. a third party vehicle exited the petrol station slip road to rejoin the main carriage way and the 2 vehicles collided. there were no injuries as a result of the accident and only minor damage to both vehicles. following the incident both vehicles pulled to the side of the report and completed an accident report on the abu dhabi police application. the vehicles then continued their journey onwards to dubai. following the collision the vehicles stopped at the road side to assess the damage and reported the incident via the police mobile app. the employee then reported the incident on arrival at the work location and an investigation was initiated. the subcontracting company suspended the driver

foreign body in eye when ip was walking towards his daily morining tool box talk as the ip was walking through the ammonia 4 plant (pump alley), where his morning tool box talk was being held, he felt discomfort in his left eye. the ip was wearing his full site ppe at the time (prescription glasses along with over glasses supplied by the amec fw stores). the ip's immediate reaction was to rub his eye, however he still felt discomfort.  the ip reported to the projects hsse advisor.  the hsse advisor could not see or locate any particles in the ip's eye,  the hsse advisor administered eye wash to try  eye wash was administered, this did not ease the discomfort.  the ip was sent to the onsite medical team (falck).  the medical team washed the ip's eye, but could not find any debris within.  the medical team brought the ip back to the safety centre, where it was suggested that he attend north tees hospital for a professional examination.  the medical staff at north tees used a swab and removed a tiny particle of metal from the ip's eye, they ip was also given chloramphericol to administer.  the medical staff advised the ip to attend the eye clinic at james cook hospital.  the ip has been taken by an amec foster wheeler employee to james cook university hospital, where we are currently waiting for an update.

mewp impacted rear end of escort vehicle (van) resulting in damage to tailgate. migrated from legacy cairs incident #31416lngp: at 0910, mewp was being escorted by van back to maintenance via the road. mewp distance between escort vehicle approximately 3m. escort slowed down to warn other traffic of mewp. mewp operator was checking vehicle traffic behind at the same time. mewp operator on realizing too close to escort vehicle went to stop however did not stop in time. knuckle part of the boom contacted the tailgate of the escort vehicle. tailgate of escort vehicle damaged. no injuries sustained. stand down for safety held withbetween all wg site management and wg construction workforceafter the incidentinvestigation underway migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

the employee received a small laceration to the left ring finger from removing a spiral wound gasket.  he was seen at the medical clinic and was released with first aid treatment. migrated from legacy cairs incident #36224on friday, january 5, 2018 at 9:15 am at dow lhc8 oc-6 a mechanical employee was removing a 42" gasket from a pancake line in a flange. as the employee was removing the gasket from the flange the spiral wound gasket came unwound. another employee picked up the damaged gasket to remove it from the work area when a piece of damaged spiral wound gasket contacted the employee's left ring finger causing a minor laceration. he was wearing the permit required ppe including hard hat, face shield, monogoogles, slicker suit, rubber boots and nitrile gloves. the employee was taken to the clinic for evaluation and was released with first aid treatment. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

a wood employee was embarked  on pce1. the ip performed the covid-19 test with a positive result. a wood employee was embarked  on pce1. the ip performed the covid-19 test with a positive result. the ip is asymptomatic the ip is asymptomatic. he received guidance from the nursing technician regarding the necessary care and will be sent home for quarantine period.

mtc; amcs (cc2210); left shoulder dislocation; ks-2016-0055 worker was in the process of repositioning a chain fall.  while changing their position on the beam, the ip’s foot slipped causing the ip to fall approx. 20 inches. the ip caught himself with his elbows resulting in a separation of the left shoulder. worker was in the process of repositioning a chain fall, while changing their position on the beam, the ip’s foot slipped causing the ip to fall 20 inches. the ip caught himself with his elbows resulting in a separation of the left shoulder.

wood worker tested positive result for covid-19 while onboard the fpso peregrino. he will disembark today for quarentine period. a wood employee was tested positive for covid-19 on a rt-pcr test while onboard the fpso peregrino. test was peformed by client. the employee is asymptomatic and will disembark today for a quarentine period.  the worker will disembark today and will be  transferred to a selected  hotel (ramada encore ribalta) in rio using a private transportation car rented by wood to perform quarantine period.

upon retrieval the 6 way gas detector got snagged on a flange of the ducting in the manhole and the rope snapped migrated from legacy cairs incident #36579on february 19th the wood civil team were assigned to the south eastern trunk sewer manhole 011 to carry out measurement of corrosion pins. the scope of works included the removal of 2 / 6 manhole covers to allow adequate room to lower the man-cage to access the lower part of the sewer, removing the manhole covers, covering opening with steel mesh/fence panels, and placing the steel barricade around the manhole.safe and mandatory work practices require gas readings before entry into the confined space. the crew reviewed the best location for the gas readings using a multirae 6 way gas detector calibrated on the 15/02/18. prior to lowering down the gas detector to get the required gas readings before entry, the crew reviewed the best point for the gas readings to be taken. the work team agreed gas reading location, was identified as the opposite side of where the entrance ladder to the sewer was, as this is known from experience as being the best point where the rope and gas detector is less likely to become entangled or caught as compared to other locations. further, selection included a suitable point to tie the rope to enable the gas detector to be suspended in the space.the gas detector was attached to a 6mm nylon rope from a clip that was spliced onto the rope. the gas detector was lowered to approximately 40 metres which was just above sewer level, and where this is classified as the head space to where the operators would be working. once readings had been taken and when pulling up the gas detector, the gas detector hit the vent ducting within the space and the rope went slack. it was at this point the person lifting the gas detector realised it had come away from the rope. when the rope was fully retrieved, it was then identified that the rope had sliced from hitting the ducting and the gas detector was absent.the spare multirae gas detector in the confined space trailer was then lowered into the space with an 18mm nylon rope to take the readings prior to entry and completing the task. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

ip grazed right hand shin when he walked past a piece of unistrut supporting a cable tray while working on a humidifier at etp ip grazed right hand shin when he walked past a piece of unistrut supporting a cable tray while working on a humidifier at etp. graze was cleaned and band aid applied. no further treatment required. first aid treatment applied, unistrut was already highlighted with red and white warning tape.

employee suddenly felt extremely dizzy and nauseous and was taken to hospital to be checked over. migrated from legacy cairs incident #34129first aider (charis kondyli) received a call at 16:31 from reception (jane dovey) to advise that there was a first aid incident on the 1st floor; no further details were provided. the first aider walked to the corridor to find out where the incident was and found mohamed azeem, simon nagle and john leitch around matt wilson, who had suddenly felt extremely dizzy / nauseous and was holding a bucket and vomiting. first assessment: first aider checked that matt was responsive and breathing ok but he looked pale and was feeling very dizzy. matt was asked if he has eating anything and he said no. he was also asked if he can sit up and he said no. the vomiting episode was ongoing.john leitch was already on the phone with 999 upon the first aiders arrival. they run a couple of checks and confirmed that an ambulance was not needed however recommended matt was taken to hospital. matt could not lie down to deal with dizziness as any head movement was making him feel nauseous. the first aider obtained the wheelchair from the first aid room and transported matt safely and with the help of john, matt, azeem to john’s car making sure he was ok along the process. john confirmed he would inform matt wife’s of the situation. they departed around 16:43.the first aider went to receptionat 16:50 and advised the facilities co-ordinator (alastair ferran) that matt’s desk required cleaning of the vomit. the facilities co-ordinator advised the first aider to tell the cleaners directly. the cleaners were standing at reception but refused to help as they stated they were not trained to clean up bodily fluids. the first aider then contacted the hssea team and the hse specialist (jody sandilands) arrived promptly and she took care of the vomit around 17:00. john later texted the first aider from the hospital to advise that matt was diagnosed with ear infection and that his wife had arrived to collect him. this report is being submitted the day after the event and matt has taken sick leave today to recover. he will be checked on when he returns to work to ensure there are no other contributing factors relating to this incident and that he feels wellenough to work. migrated from legacy cairs - see detailed description

employee tested positive for covid-19. employee tested positive for covid-19:employee had symptoms of covid-19, went for testing  and confirmed positive on 18th oct 2020.  employee was hospitalized from 19th oct 2020 to 25th oct 2020. on 26th oct 2020, onwards employee is on home quarantine at vaniyambadi (a major town located at 202 km west of chennai) as per doctor's advice. employee has been working from home since 23rd march 2020.  employee is contacted for any support needed.

roadway collision-moving in opposite directions, oncoming employee was driving a mini bus in san antonio city and was involved in a head on collision. the employee was admitted to the hospital for surgery to treat a laceration to right eye.

caught in running equipment or machinery during maintenance, cleaning  an employee was attempting to remove a jam in a box printing machine when his glove and right hand were caught by the machine rollers, pinching/crushing his middle and index fingers. he was hospitalized for surgery.

text: other fall to lower level, unspecified an employee was engaged in hvac demolition activities on the roof. as he was attempting to push parts of the demolished hvac unit off of the roof, his glove became stuck to the unit. he was pulled off the roof with the unit to the ground, suffering artery damage that required surgery and a cracked skull.

text: other fall to lower level 16 to 20 feet on march 5, 2021, an employee was engaged in the task of adding backstops to the highest shelf of a storage racking system in the pre-blend department. the employee used an extension ladder to access the highest shelf. the employee attempted to step from the ladder onto the shelf when the bottom of the ladder slid out due to a slippery floor. the employee fell  approximately 20 feet to the concrete floor and suffered fractured vertebrae. the employee was hospitalized.

text: collision between water vehicle and object between around 4:30 and 4:45 p.m., two employees were motoring a skiff down a river when the skiff hydroplaned and struck the shoreline. the employees were both injured: one suffered upper body injuries (suspected broken ribs) and a concussion and the other suffered facial and leg injuries. both were hospitalized.

direct exposure to electricity, greater than 220 volts an employee turned his back on a live high-voltage line as he was uncovering an electrical power he was about to work on, causing burns to his neck and right thigh. he was hospitalized.

other animal bites, nonvenomous on 07/09/2015, an employee delivering a package to a residence was bitten on both hands by the inhabitant's dog. the employee was later hospitalized when both hands became swollen.

caught in running equipment or machinery during maintenance, cleaning  an employee was attempting to unclog a jammed vacuum unit when his right hand entered the energized unit. his right index finger was then caught between the vacuum's airlock and flange, resulting in a partial finger amputation.

category: general injury, fall from or working at height issue
text: other fall to lower level, unspecified an employee was sand blasting on the outside wall of a water tower when he lost his balance and fell at an angle. he hit the ground, breaking one rib and puncturing a lung.

category: fall from or working at height issue, slips & trips
text: other fall to lower level, unspecified an employee climbed over a screen gable over a pool in order to pull a tarp down. he slipped because the aluminum was icy and fell on top of a deck chair resulting in a lower back injury.

category: general injury, hand or arm injury
text: struck by discharged or flying object, n.e.c. an employee was standing on a bridge sidewalk when a passing vehicle with a ladder rack snagged a vertical hand line hanging from the upper portions of the bridge. the rope struck the employee along the midsection and threw him against the bridge's hand railing. he suffered two fractured ribs, a mild concussion, and minor bleeding in the spleen.

overexertion in lifting-single episode on or about july 7, a window clerk was handling an express mail package when she felt a pop in her neck. the employee went to hospital the next day for a neck injury.

category: foot or leg injury, lifting or moving loads, vehicle incident general
text: part of occupantís body caught between vehicle and other object in nonroadway transport incident an employee was operating a stand-up forklift truck when he struck a guardrail, lacerating his right leg and requiring hospitalization.

jack-knifed or overturned, nonroadway an employee was operating a rough-terrain forklift when it turned over on the boom side. the employee suffered a partially collapsed lung, a broken scapula, and broken ribs.
contact with hot objects or substances an employee was using a hose to unload a tank of hot asphalt when the hose broke, allowing the asphalt to splash and burn the employee.

category: dropped object or material, hand or arm injury
text: struck by falling object or equipment, unspecified an employee received an injury to the right middle finger that required surgery and hospitalization. the employee's finger was caught between a pump plunger and the catwalk when the pump plunger fell to the catwalk.

category: hand or arm injury, fall from or working at height issue, head or face injury
text: other fall to lower level 16 to 20 feet during roofing installation, an employee fell 18 feet from the roof to the ground and sustained broken wrists and facial fractures. fall protection was not being worn at the time.
struck against moving part of machinery or equipment employee was using a band saw in the commissary's butcher shop area to process meat for resale when he amputated the tip of his left thumb.

category: dropped object or material, line strike, hand or arm injury
text: struck by falling object or equipment, n.e.c. an employee and a coworker were removing a 7-inch pipe from a rack when the pipe fell from the rack and struck the employee's left hand, amputating the middle and ring fingers.

caught in running equipment or machinery during regular operation an employee was loading a new piece of metal on a machine after stopping it. the machine engaged and the shear blade amputated three of the employee's fingers.

category: general injury, fall from or working at height issue
text: other fall to lower level, unspecified an employee was standing on stacked milk crates to reach a higher shelf when she lost her balance and fell. her rib struck the crates and was fractured.

category: foot or leg injury, hand or arm injury
text: injured by slipping or swinging object held by injured worker at 9:35 am on june 16, 2020, an employee was cutting potatoes to make french fries when the potato cutter amputated his right index fingertip.

category: hand or arm injury, knife incident
text: injured by slipping or swinging object held by injured worker an employee was cutting lettuce with a standard chef's cutting knife when the blade amputated the employee's thumb tip.

caught in running equipment or machinery during regular operation on september 17, 2016, while operating a chamfering machine, an employee's third left finger was amputated in the machine's point of operation. the machine's safety buttons were bypassed at the time.

exposure through intact skin, eyes, or other exposed tissue an employee was moving buckets of liquid potassium hydroxide and some of the liquid spilled onto his foot causing severe chemical burns. the employee was hospitalized.

category: dropped object or material, back injury, lifting or moving loads, vehicle incident general
text: struck by object falling from vehicle or machinery-other than vehicle part an employee was near a truck loaded with pipes when a pipe shifted and rolled off the truck. the employee was pinned between the pipe and a stack of pipes, fracturing his pelvis.

caught in running equipment or machinery during regular operation an employee was buffing a shaft while operating a lathe when a piece of the employee's clothing was caught by the lathe, resulting in a broken right forearm.

struck by object or equipment dropped by injured worker an employee was stacking a pallet on top of a load of stacked pallets. the pallet fell on top of the employee's chest as the employee was handling the pallet.

caught in running equipment or machinery during regular operation an employee was guiding boxes through a transition point between two conveyors when the employee's left hand entered a gap between the conveyor belt and the frame, fracturing the left index finger.

caught in running equipment or machinery during regular operation an employee was holding a mandrel while operating a hydraulic press brake. when he engaged the foot pedal, his fingers were caught between the mandrel and the top of the forming die. his right index and middle fingertips were amputated.

category: hand or arm injury, fall from or working at height issue, slips & trips
text: other fall to lower level, unspecified an employee was descending an a-frame ladder when he slipped and fell on a 4-foot long light bulb tube that was set near his ladder. he suffered lacerations and cuts, as shards of glass were embedded in his right arm and lips.

injured by slipping or swinging object held by injured worker an employee was running cable through a wall and attaching it to a wall plate. he needed another screw to attach the plate to the wall. when he drilled the screw, it drilled through his left hand.

caught in or compressed by equipment or objects, unspecified an employee was moving silo panels when his left thumb was caught in a pinch point between a jib and a strap, resulting in a left thumb amputation.

category: fall from or working at height issue, head or face injury
text: other fall to lower level, unspecified an employee was on a ladder changing a light bulb when she fell to the floor below. she was hospitalized with head trauma and a concussion.

category: general injury, fall from or working at height issue, slips & trips
text: other fall to lower level, unspecified an employee was climbing down a ladder from a trailer. he fell to the ground, his head striking a girder as he fell. he suffered a broken right hip socket.

category: fall from or working at height issue
text: other fall to lower level less than 6 feet an employee was removing the back gate of a flat bed truck fitted with a removeable fence. the employee fell from the loading dock less than 4 feet to the ground. the employee later collapsed in the parking lot when trying to leave for the day and was hospitalized.

explosion of nonpressurized vapors, gases, or liquids an employee was servicing a propane truck in a garage when a leak from the truck ignited and caused an explosion. the employee was burned severely and hospitalized.

caught in running equipment or machinery during maintenance, cleaning  on august 10, 2017, an employee was on a feed conveyor clearing material from an overhead conveyor when the employee's left ring and middle fingers contacted the chain and sprocket. the employee's fingers had to be surgically amputated. the overhead conveyor was unguarded at the time.

struck against moving part of machinery or equipment an employee was removing filters in a blower's fan unit when the moving fan blade lacerated three fingertips and partially amputated the middle fingertip above the nail.

category: dropped object or material, lifting or moving loads, hand or arm injury
text: struck by falling object or equipment, n.e.c. an employee was dismantling an overhead conveyor when the connection point for the rigging gave way and the conveyor fell, amputating the employee's left pinky finger at the first joint (just below the nailbed).
